column2: Thus we find the Supreme Court sustaining the proposition that the Federal Government has power to establish a temporary civil government within the limits of a Territory, but that it can enact no law which will endure beyond the temporary purposes for which such government was established.

column2: 30' north latitude, was null and void _ab incepto_, if it had not been repealed by a recent act of Congress. (Compare iv, Statutes at Large, p. 848, and x, Statutes at Large, p. 289.) column2: Fortunate indeed was it for the public peace that land and religion had been decided--those questions on which men might reason had been the foundation of judicial decision--before that which drives all reason, it seems, from the mind of man, came to be presented the question whether Cuffee should be kept in his normal condition or not; the question whether the Congress of the United States could decide what might or might not be property in a Territory--the case being that of an officer of the army sent into a Territory to perform his public duty, having taken with him his negro slave.

column2: And here let me say, I can not see how those who agreed on a former occasion that the constitutional right of the slaveholder to take his property into the Territory--the constitutional power of the Congress and the constitutional power of the Territory to legislate upon that subject--should be a judicial question, can now attempt to escape the operation of an opinion which covers the exact political question which, it was known beforehand, the Court would be called upon to decide. Decided in strictness of technical language, it was known it could not be.

column2: Hundreds, thousands, a vast variety of cases may arise, and centuries elapse, and leave that Court, if our Union still exists, deciding questions in relation to that character of property in the Territories; but the great and fundamental idea was that, after thirty years of angry controversy, dividing the people and paralyzing the arm of the Federal Government, some umpire should be sought which would compose the difficulty and set it upon a footing to leave us in future to proceed in peace; and that umpire was selected which the Constitution had provided to decide questions of law.
column3: Hundreds, thousands, a vast variety of cases may arise, and centuries elapse, and leave that Court, if our Union still exists, deciding questions in relation to that character of property in the Territories; but the great and fundamental idea was that, after thirty years of angry controversy, dividing the people and paralyzing the arm of the Federal Government, some umpire should be sought which would compose the difficulty and set it upon a footing to leave us in future to proceed in peace; and that umpire was selected which the Constitution had provided to decide questions of law.

column2: I ask my friend to read some extracts from the decision.

column2: Mr. Chesnut read as follows, from the case of Dred Scott _vs._ Sandford, pp. 55-57:
column3: mr Chesnut read as follows, from the case of Dred Scott underscore vs underscore Sandford, p p. fifty five to fifty seven:

column2: The Territory being a part of the United States, the Government and the citizen both enter it under the authority of the Constitution, with their respective rights defined and marked out; and the Federal Government can exercise no power over his person or property beyond what that instrument confers, nor lawfully deny any right which it has reserved....	The Territory being a part of the United States, the Government and the citizen both enter it under the authority of the Constitution, with their respective rights defined and marked out; and the Federal Government can exercise no power over his person or property beyond what that instrument confers, nor lawfully deny any right which it has reserved....
column3: true

column2: The powers over person and property, of which we speak, are not only not granted to Congress, but are in express terms denied, and they are forbidden to exercise them.	The powers over person and property, of which we speak, are not only not granted to Congress, but are in express terms denied, and they are forbidden to exercise them.
column3: true

column2: And this prohibition is not confined to the States, but the words are general, and extend to the whole territory over which the Constitution gives it power to legislate, including those portions of it remaining under territorial government, as well as that covered by States.
column3: And this prohibition is not confined to the States, but the words are general, and extend to the whole territory over which the Constitution gives it power to legislate, including those portions of it remaining under territorial government, as well as that covered by States.

column2: It is a total absence of power everywhere within the dominion of the United States, and places the citizens of a Territory, so far as these rights are concerned, on the same footing with citizens of the States, and guards them as firmly and plainly against any inroads which the General Government might attempt under the plea of implied or incidental powers.
column3: It is a total absence of power everywhere within the dominion of the United States, and places the citizens of a Territory, so far as these rights are concerned, on the same footing with citizens of the States, and guards them as firmly and plainly against any inroads which the General Government might attempt under the plea of implied or incidental powers.

column2: And if Congress itself can not do this--if it is beyond the powers conferred on the Federal Government--it will be admitted, we presume, that it could not authorize a territorial government to exercise them.
column3: And if Congress itself can not do this-if it is beyond the powers conferred on the Federal Government-it will be admitted, we presume, that it could not authorize a territorial government to exercise them.

column2: It could confer no power on any local government, established by its authority, to violate the provisions of the Constitution....
column3: It could confer no power on any local government, established by its authority, to violate the provisions of the Constitution....

column2: And if the Constitution recognizes the right of property of the master in the slave, and makes no distinction between that description of property and other property owned by a citizen, no tribunal, acting under the authority of the United States, whether it be legislative, executive, or judicial, has a right to draw such a distinction, or deny to it the benefit of the provisions and guarantees which have been provided for the protection of private property against the encroachments of the Government....	And if the Constitution recognizes the right of property of the master in the slave, and makes no distinction between that description of property and other property owned by a citizen, no tribunal, acting under the authority of the United States, whether it be legislative, executive, or judicial, has a right to draw such a distinction, or deny to it the benefit of the provisions and guarantees which have been provided for the protection of private property against the encroachments of the Government....
column3: false

column2: This is done in plain words--too plain to be misunderstood.	This is done in plain words-too plain to be misunderstood.
column3: true

column2: And no word can be found in the Constitution which gives Congress a greater power over slave-property, or which entitles property of that kind to less protection than property of any other description.
column3: And no word can be found in the Constitution which gives Congress a greater power over slave property, or which entitles property of that kind to less protection than property of any other description.

column2: The only power conferred is the power coupled with the duty of guarding and protecting the owner in his rights.
column3: The only power conferred is the power coupled with the duty of guarding and protecting the owner in his rights.

column2: Upon these considerations, it is the opinion of the Court that the act of Congress which prohibited a citizen from holding and owning property of this kind, in the territory of the United States north of the line therein mentioned, is not warranted by the Constitution, and is therefore void; and that neither Dred Scott himself, nor any of his family, were made free by being carried into this territory, even if they had been carried there by the owner, with the intention of becoming a permanent resident.
column3: Upon these considerations, it is the opinion of the Court that the act of Congress which prohibited a citizen from holding and owning property of this kind, in the territory of the United States north of the line therein mentioned, is not warranted by the Constitution, and is therefore void; and that neither Dred Scott himself, nor any of his family, were made free by being carried into this territory, even if they had been carried there by the owner, with the intention of becoming a permanent resident.

column2: Mr. Davis: Here, then, Mr. President, I say the umpire selected as the referee in the controversy has decided that neither the Congress nor its agent, the territorial government, has the power to invade or impair the right of property within the limits of a Territory.

column2: I will not inquire whether it be technically a decision or not.
column3: I will not inquire whether it be technically a decision or not.

column2: It was obligatory on those who selected the umpire and agreed to abide by the award.
column3: It was obligatory on those who selected the umpire and agreed to abide by the award.

column2: It is well known to those who have been associated with me in the two Houses of Congress that, from the commencement of the question, I have been the determined opponent of what is called squatter sovereignty.
column3: It is well known to those who have been associated with me in the two Houses of Congress that, from the commencement of the question, I have been the determined opponent of what is called squatter sovereignty.

column2: I never gave it countenance, and I am now least of all disposed to give it quarter.
column3: I never gave it countenance, and I am now least of all disposed to give it quarter.

column2: In 1848 it made its appearance for good purposes.
column3: In eighteen forty eight it made its appearance for good purposes.

column2: It was ushered in by a great and good man.
column3: It was ushered in by a great and good man.

column2: He brought it forward because of that distrust which he had in the capacity of the Government to bear the rude shock to which it was exposed.
column3: He brought it forward because of that distrust which he had in the capacity of the Government to bear the rude shock to which it was exposed.

column2: His apprehension, no doubt, to some extent sharpened and directed his patriotism, and his reflection led him to a conclusion to which, I doubt not, to-day he adheres as tenaciously as ever; but from which it was my fortune, good or ill, to dissent when his letter was read to me in manuscript--I being, together with some other persons, asked, though not by the writer, whether or not it should be sent.

column2: At the first blush I believed it to be a fallacy--a fallacy fraught with mischief; that it escaped an issue which was upon us which it was our duty to meet; that it escaped it by a side path, which led to a greater danger.
column3: At the first blush I believed it to be a fallacy-a fallacy fraught with mischief; that it escaped an issue which was upon us which it was our duty to meet; that it escaped it by a side path, which led to a greater danger.

column2: I thought it a fallacy which would surely be exploded. I doubted then, and still more for some time afterward, when held to a dread responsibility for the position which I occupied.
column3: I thought it a fallacy which would surely be exploded. I doubted then, and still more for some time afterward, when held to a dread responsibility for the position which I occupied.

column2: I doubted whether I should live to see that fallacy exploded.
column3: I doubted whether I should live to see that fallacy exploded.

column2: It has been more speedily, and, to the country, more injuriously than I anticipated.
column3: It has been more speedily, and, to the country, more injuriously than I anticipated.

column2: In the mean time, what has been its operation?
column3: In the mean time, what has been its operation?

column2: Let Kansas speak--the first great field on which the trial was made.
column3: Let Kansas speak-the first great field on which the trial was made.

column2: What was then the consequence? The Federal Government withdrawing control, leaving the contending sections, excited to the highest point upon this question, each to send forth its army, Kansas became the battle-field, and Kansas the cry, which wellnigh led to civil war.
column3: What was then the consequence? The Federal Government withdrawing control, leaving the contending sections, excited to the highest point upon this question, each to send forth its army, Kansas became the battle field, and Kansas the cry, which wellnigh led to civil war.

column2: This was the first fruit.
column3: This was the first fruit.

column2: More deadly than the fatal upas, its effect was not limited to the mere spot of ground on which the dew fell from its leaves, but it spread throughout the United States; it kindled all which had been collected for years of inflammable material.
column3: More deadly than the fatal upas, its effect was not limited to the mere spot of ground on which the dew fell from its leaves, but it spread throughout the United States; it kindled all which had been collected for years of inflammable material.

column2: It was owing to the strength of our Government and the good sense of the quiet masses of the people that it did not wrap our country in one widespread conflagration.
column3: It was owing to the strength of our Government and the good sense of the quiet masses of the people that it did not wrap our country in one widespread conflagration.

column2: What right had Congress then, or what right has it now, to abdicate any power conferred upon it as trustee of the States?
column3: What right had Congress then, or what right has it now, to abdicate any power conferred upon it as trustee of the States?

column2: What right had Congress then, or has it now, to shrink from the performance of a duty because the mere counters spread on the table may be swept off, when they have not answered the purposes for which they were placed?
column3: What right had Congress then, or has it now, to shrink from the performance of a duty because the mere counters spread on the table may be swept off, when they have not answered the purposes for which they were placed?

column2: What is it to you, or me, or any one, when we weigh our own continuation in place against the great interests of which we are conservators; against the welfare of the country, and the liberty of our posterity to the remotest ages?
column3: What is it to you, or me, or any one, when we weigh our own continuation in place against the great interests of which we are conservators; against the welfare of the country, and the liberty of our posterity to the remotest ages?

column2: What is it, I say, which can be counted in the balance on our side against the performance of that duty which is imposed upon us? If any one believes Congress has not the constitutional power, he acts conscientiously in insisting upon Congress not usurping it.
column3: What is it, I say, which can be counted in the balance on our side against the performance of that duty which is imposed upon us? If any one believes Congress has not the constitutional power, he acts conscientiously in insisting upon Congress not usurping it.

column2: If any one believes that the squatters upon the lands of the United States within a Territory are invested with sovereignty, having won it by some of those processes unknown to history, without grant, or without revolution, without money and without price, he, adhering to the theory, may pursue it to its conclusion.
column3: If any one believes that the squatters upon the lands of the United States within a Territory are invested with sovereignty, having won it by some of those processes unknown to history, without grant, or without revolution, without money and without price, he, adhering to the theory, may pursue it to its conclusion.

column2: To the first class, those who claim sovereign power over the Territories for Congress, I say, lay your hand upon the Constitution, and find there the warrant of your authority.
column3: To the first class, those who claim sovereign power over the Territories for Congress, I say, lay your hand upon the Constitution, and find there the warrant of your authority.

column2: Of the second, those of whom I have last spoken, I ask, in the Constitution, reason, right, or justice, what is there to sustain your theory?
column3: Of the second, those of whom I have last spoken, I ask, in the Constitution, reason, right, or justice, what is there to sustain your theory?

column2: The phraseology which has been employed on this question seems to me to betray a strange confusion of ideas--to speak of a sovereignty, a plenary legislative power deriving its power from an agent; a sovereignty, held subject to articles with the formation of which that sovereignty had nothing to do; a compact to which it was not a party! You say to a sovereign: "A and B have agreed on certain terms between themselves, and you must govern your conduct according to them; yet I do not deny your sovereignty!" That is, the power to do as they please, provided it conforms to the rule which others chose to lay down!
column3: The phraseology which has been employed on this question seems to me to betray a strange confusion of ideas-to speak of a sovereignty, a plenary legislative power deriving its power from an agent; a sovereignty, held subject to articles with the formation of which that sovereignty had nothing to do; a compact to which it was not a party! You say to a sovereign: "A and B have agreed on certain terms between themselves, and you must govern your conduct according to them; yet I do not deny your sovereignty!" That is, the power to do as they please, provided it conforms to the rule which others chose to lay down!

column2: Can this be a definition of sovereignty?
column3: Can this be a definition of sovereignty?

column2: But again, sir, nothing seems to me more illogical than the argument that this power is acquired by a grant from the Congress, connected with the other argument that Congress have not got the power to do the act themselves; that is to say, that the recipient takes more than the giver possessed; that a Territorial Legislature can do anything which a State Legislature can do, and that "subject to the Constitution" means merely the restraints imposed upon both.
column3: But again, sir, nothing seems to me more illogical than the argument that this power is acquired by a grant from the Congress, connected with the other argument that Congress have not got the power to do the act themselves; that is to say, that the recipient takes more than the giver possessed; that a Territorial Legislature can do anything which a State Legislature can do, and that "subject to the Constitution" means merely the restraints imposed upon both.

column2: This is confounding the whole theory and the history of our Government.
column3: This is confounding the whole theory and the history of our Government.

column2: The States were the grantors; they made the compact; they gave the Federal agent its powers; they inhibited themselves from doing certain things, and all else they retained to themselves.
column3: The States were the grantors; they made the compact; they gave the Federal agent its powers; they inhibited themselves from doing certain things, and all else they retained to themselves.

column2: This Federal agent got just so much as the States chose to give--no more.
column3: This Federal agent got just so much as the States chose to give-no more.

column2: It could do nothing save by warrant of the authority of the grant made by the States.
column3: It could do nothing save by warrant of the authority of the grant made by the States.

column2: Therefore its powers are not comparable to the powers of the State Legislature, because one is the creature of grant, and the other the exponent of sovereign power.
column3: Therefore its powers are not comparable to the powers of the State Legislature, because one is the creature of grant, and the other the exponent of sovereign power.

column2: The Supreme Court have covered the whole ground of the relation of the Congress to the Territorial Legislatures--the agent of the States and the agent of the Congress--and the restrictions put upon the one are those put upon the other, in language so clear as to render it needless further to labor the subject.
column3: The Supreme Court have covered the whole ground of the relation of the Congress to the Territorial Legislatures-the agent of the States and the agent of the Congress-and the restrictions put upon the one are those put upon the other, in language so clear as to render it needless further to labor the subject.

column2: In 1850, following the promulgation of this notion of squatter sovereignty, we had the idea of non-intervention introduced into the Senate of the United States, and it is strange to me how that idea has expanded.
column3: In eighteen fifty, following the promulgation of this notion of squatter sovereignty, we had the idea of non intervention introduced into the Senate of the United States, and it is strange to me how that idea has expanded.

column2: It seems to have been more malleable than gold; to have been hammered out to an extent that covers boundless regions undiscovered by those who proclaimed the doctrine.
column3: It seems to have been more malleable than gold; to have been hammered out to an extent that covers boundless regions undiscovered by those who proclaimed the doctrine.

column2: Non-intervention then meant, as the debates show, that Congress should neither prohibit nor establish slavery in the Territories.
column3: Non intervention then meant, as the debates show, that Congress should neither prohibit nor establish slavery in the Territories.

column2: That I hold to now.
column3: That I hold to now.

column2: Will any one suppose that Congress then meant by non-intervention that Congress should legislate in no regard in respect to property in slaves?
column3: Will any one suppose that Congress then meant by non intervention that Congress should legislate in no regard in respect to property in slaves?

column2: Why, sir, the very acts which they passed at the time refute it.
column3: Why, sir, the very acts which they passed at the time refute it.

column2: There is the fugitive slave law, and that abomination of laws which assumed to confiscate the property of a citizen who should attempt to bring it into this District with intent to remove it to sell it at some other time and at some other place.
column3: There is the fugitive slave law, and that abomination of laws which assumed to confiscate the property of a citizen who should attempt to bring it into this District with intent to remove it to sell it at some other time and at some other place.

column2: Congress acted then upon the subject--acted beyond the limit of its authority, as I believed, confidently believed; and, if ever that act comes before the Supreme Court, I feel satisfied they will declare it null and void.
column3: Congress acted then upon the subject-acted beyond the limit of its authority, as I believed, confidently believed; and, if ever that act comes before the Supreme Court, I feel satisfied they will declare it null and void.

column2: Are we to understand that those men, thus acting at the very moment, intended by non-intervention to deny and repudiate the laws they were then creating?
column3: Are we to understand that those men, thus acting at the very moment, intended by non intervention to deny and repudiate the laws they were then creating?

column3: On june eighteenth eighteen fifty, I had introduced an amendment to the compromise bill, providing:

column2: And that all laws, or parts of laws, usages, or customs, preexisting in the Territories acquired by the United States from Mexico, and which in said Territories restrict, abridge, or obstruct, the full enjoyment of any right of person or property of a citizen of the United States, as recognized or guaranteed by the Constitution or laws of the United States, are hereby declared and shall be held as repealed.

column2: President: I thought that upon this subject there had been a clear understanding in the Senate that the Senate would not decide itself upon the _lex loci_ as it respects slavery; that the Senate would not allow the Territorial Legislature to pass any law upon that question.
column3: President: I thought that upon this subject there had been a clear understanding in the Senate that the Senate would not decide itself upon the underscore lex loci underscore as it respects slavery; that the Senate would not allow the Territorial Legislature to pass any law upon that question.

column2: If non-intervention means that we shall not have protection for our property in slaves, then I always was, and always shall be, opposed to it.
column3: If non intervention means that we shall not have protection for our property in slaves, then I always was, and always shall be, opposed to it.

column2: If it means that we shall not have the protection of the law because it would favor slaveholders, that Congress shall not legislate so as to secure to us the benefits of the Constitution, then I am opposed to non-intervention, and shall always be opposed to it."--(_Appendix to Congressional Globe_, Thirty-first Congress, first session, p. 919.)
column3: If it means that we shall not have the protection of the law because it would favor slaveholders, that Congress shall not legislate so as to secure to us the benefits of the Constitution, then I am opposed to non intervention, and shall always be opposed to it."--(underscore Appendix to Congressional Globe underscore, Thirty first Congress, first session, p. nine hundred nineteen.)

column2: Mr. Downs, one of the Committee of Thirteen, and an advocate of the measures, said:
column3: mr Downs, one of the Committee of Thirteen, and an advocate of the measures, said:

column2: What I understand by non-intervention is, an interposition of Congress prohibiting, or establishing, or interfering with slavery.--(_Appendix to Congressional Globe_, Thirty-first Congress, first session, p. 99.)
column3: What I understand by non intervention is, an interposition of Congress prohibiting, or establishing, or interfering with slavery.--(underscore Appendix to Congressional Globe underscore, Thirty first Congress, first session, p. ninety nine.)

column2: By what species of legerdemain this doctrine of non-intervention has come to extend to a paralysis of the Government on the whole subject, to exclude the Congress from any kind of legislation whatever, I am at a loss to conceive.
column3: By what species of legerdemain this doctrine of non intervention has come to extend to a paralysis of the Government on the whole subject, to exclude the Congress from any kind of legislation whatever, I am at a loss to conceive.

column2: Certain it is, it was not the theory of that period, and it was not contended for in all the controversies we had then.
column3: Certain it is, it was not the theory of that period, and it was not contended for in all the controversies we had then.

column2: I had no faith in it then; I considered it an evasion; I held that the duty of Congress ought to be performed; that the issue was before us, and ought to be met, the sooner the better; that truth would prevail if presented to the people; borne down to-day, it would rise up to-morrow; and I stood then on the same general plea which I am making now.
column3: I had no faith in it then; I considered it an evasion; I held that the duty of Congress ought to be performed; that the issue was before us, and ought to be met, the sooner the better; that truth would prevail if presented to the people; borne down to day, it would rise up to morrow; and I stood then on the same general plea which I am making now.

column2: Douglas] and myself differed at that time, as I presume we do now.

column2: We differed radically then.

column2: He opposed every proposition which I made, voting against propositions to give power to a Territorial Legislature to protect slave-property which should be taken there; to remove the obstructions of the Mexican laws; voting for a proposition to exclude the conclusion that slavery might be taken there; voting for the proposition expressly to prohibit its introduction; voting for the proposition to keep in force the laws of Mexico which prohibited it.
column3: He opposed every proposition which I made, voting against propositions to give power to a Territorial Legislature to protect slave property which should be taken there; to remove the obstructions of the Mexican laws; voting for a proposition to exclude the conclusion that slavery might be taken there; voting for the proposition expressly to prohibit its introduction; voting for the proposition to keep in force the laws of Mexico which prohibited it.

column2: Some of these votes, it is but just to him I should say, I think he gave perforce of his instructions; but others of them, I think it is equally fair to suppose, were outside of the limits of any instructions which could have been given before the fact.

column2: In 1854, advancing in this same general line of thought, the Congress, in enacting territorial bills, left out a provision which had before been usually contained in them, requiring the Legislature of the Territory to submit its laws to the Congress of the United States.
column3: In eighteen fifty four, advancing in this same general line of thought, the Congress, in enacting territorial bills, left out a provision which had before been usually contained in them, requiring the Legislature of the Territory to submit its laws to the Congress of the United States.

column2: It has been sometimes assumed that this was the recognition of the power of the Territorial Legislature to exercise plenary legislation, as might that of a State.
column3: It has been sometimes assumed that this was the recognition of the power of the Territorial Legislature to exercise plenary legislation, as might that of a State.

column2: It will be remembered that, when our present form of government was instituted, there were those who believed the Federal Government should have the power of revision over the laws of a State. It was long and ably contended for in the Convention which formed the Constitution; and one of the compromises which was made was an appellate power--to lodge power in the Supreme Court to decide all questions of constitutional law.
column3: It will be remembered that, when our present form of government was instituted, there were those who believed the Federal Government should have the power of revision over the laws of a State. It was long and ably contended for in the Convention which formed the Constitution; and one of the compromises which was made was an appellate power-to lodge power in the Supreme Court to decide all questions of constitutional law.

column2: But did this omission of the obligation to send here the laws of the Territories work this grant of power to the Territorial Legislature? Certainly not; it could not; and that it did not is evinced by the fact that, at a subsequent period, the organic act was revised because the legislation of the Territory of Kansas was offensive to the Congress of the United States.
column3: But did this omission of the obligation to send here the laws of the Territories work this grant of power to the Territorial Legislature? Certainly not; it could not; and that it did not is evinced by the fact that, at a subsequent period, the organic act was revised because the legislation of the Territory of Kansas was offensive to the Congress of the United States.

column2: Congress could not abdicate its authority; it could not abandon its trust; and, when it omitted the requirement that the laws should be sent back, it created a _casus_ which required it to act without the official records being laid before it, as they would have been if the obligation had existed.
column3: Congress could not abdicate its authority; it could not abandon its trust; and, when it omitted the requirement that the laws should be sent back, it created a underscore casus underscore which required it to act without the official records being laid before it, as they would have been if the obligation had existed.

column2: That was all the difference.
column3: That was all the difference.

column2: It was not enforcing upon the agent the obligation to send the information.
column3: It was not enforcing upon the agent the obligation to send the information.

column2: It left Congress, as to its power, just where it was.
column3: It left Congress, as to its power, just where it was.

column2: I find myself physically unable to go as fully into the subject as I intended, and therefore, omitting a reference to those acts, suffice it to say that here was the recognition of the obligation of Congress to interpose against a Territorial Legislature for the protection of personal right. That is what we ask of Congress now.
column3: I find myself physically unable to go as fully into the subject as I intended, and therefore, omitting a reference to those acts, suffice it to say that here was the recognition of the obligation of Congress to interpose against a Territorial Legislature for the protection of personal right. That is what we ask of Congress now.

column2: I am not disposed to ask this Congress to go into speculative legislation.
column3: I am not disposed to ask this Congress to go into speculative legislation.

column2: I am not one of those who would willingly see this Congress enact a code to be applied to all Territories and for all time to come.
column3: I am not one of those who would willingly see this Congress enact a code to be applied to all Territories and for all time to come.

column2: I only ask that cases, as they arise, may be met according to the exigency.
column3: I only ask that cases, as they arise, may be met according to the exigency.

column2: I ask that when personal and property rights in the Territories are not protected, then the Congress, by existing laws and governmental machinery, shall intervene and provide such means as will secure in each case, as far as may be, an adequate remedy.
column3: I ask that when personal and property rights in the Territories are not protected, then the Congress, by existing laws and governmental machinery, shall intervene and provide such means as will secure in each case, as far as may be, an adequate remedy.

column2: I ask no slave code, nor horse code, nor machine code. I ask that the Territorial Legislature be made to understand beforehand that the Congress of the United States does not concede to them the power to interfere with the rights of person or property guaranteed by the Constitution, and that it will apply the remedy, if the Territorial Legislature should so far forget its duty, so far transcend its power, as to commit that violation of right.
column3: I ask no slave code, nor horse code, nor machine code. I ask that the Territorial Legislature be made to understand beforehand that the Congress of the United States does not concede to them the power to interfere with the rights of person or property guaranteed by the Constitution, and that it will apply the remedy, if the Territorial Legislature should so far forget its duty, so far transcend its power, as to commit that violation of right.

column2: That is the announcement of the fifth resolution.
column3: That is the announcement of the fifth resolution.

column2: These are the general views which I entertain of our right of protection and the duty of the Government.
column3: These are the general views which I entertain of our right of protection and the duty of the Government.

column2: They are those which are entertained by the constituency I have the honor to represent, whose delegation has recently announced those principles at Charleston.
column3: They are those which are entertained by the constituency I have the honor to represent, whose delegation has recently announced those principles at Charleston.

column2: I honor them, and I approve their conduct.
column3: I honor them, and I approve their conduct.

column2: I think their bearing was worthy of the mother-State which sent them there; and I doubt not she will receive them with joy and gratitude.
column3: I think their bearing was worthy of the mother State which sent them there; and I doubt not she will receive them with joy and gratitude.

column2: They have asserted and vindicated her equality of right.
column3: They have asserted and vindicated her equality of right.

column2: By that asserted equality of right I doubt not she will stand.
column3: By that asserted equality of right I doubt not she will stand.

column2: For weal or for woe, for prosperity or adversity, for the preservation of the great blessings which we enjoy, or the trial of a new and separate condition, I trust Mississippi never will surrender the smallest atom of the sovereignty, independence, and equality, to which she was born, to avoid any danger or any sacrifice to which she may hereby be exposed.
column3: For weal or for woe, for prosperity or adversity, for the preservation of the great blessings which we enjoy, or the trial of a new and separate condition, I trust Mississippi never will surrender the smallest atom of the sovereignty, independence, and equality, to which she was born, to avoid any danger or any sacrifice to which she may hereby be exposed.

column2: The sixth resolution of the series declares at what time a State may form a Constitution and decide upon her domestic institutions.
column3: The sixth resolution of the series declares at what time a State may form a Constitution and decide upon her domestic institutions.

column2: I deny this right to the territorial condition, because the Territory belongs in common to the States.
column3: I deny this right to the territorial condition, because the Territory belongs in common to the States.

column2: Every citizen of the United States, as a joint owner of that Territory, has a right to go into it with any property which he may possess.
column3: Every citizen of the United States, as a joint owner of that Territory, has a right to go into it with any property which he may possess.

column2: These territorial inhabitants require municipal law, police, and government.
column3: These territorial inhabitants require municipal law, police, and government.

column2: They should have them, but they should be restricted to their own necessities.
column3: They should have them, but they should be restricted to their own necessities.

column2: They have no right within their municipal power to attempt to decide the rights of the people of the States.
column3: They have no right within their municipal power to attempt to decide the rights of the people of the States.

column2: They have no right to exclude any citizen of the United States from owning and equally enjoying this common possession; it is for the purpose of preserving order, and giving protection to rights of person and property, that a municipal territorial government should be instituted.
column3: They have no right to exclude any citizen of the United States from owning and equally enjoying this common possession; it is for the purpose of preserving order, and giving protection to rights of person and property, that a municipal territorial government should be instituted.

column2: The last resolution refers to a law founded on a provision of the Constitution, which contains an obligation of faith to every State of the Union; and that obligation of faith has been violated by thirteen States of the Confederacy--as many as originally fought the battles of the Revolution and established the Confederation.
column3: The last resolution refers to a law founded on a provision of the Constitution, which contains an obligation of faith to every State of the Union; and that obligation of faith has been violated by thirteen States of the Confederacy-as many as originally fought the battles of the Revolution and established the Confederation.

column2: Is it to be expected that a compact thus broken in part, violated in its important features, will be regarded as binding in all else?
column3: Is it to be expected that a compact thus broken in part, violated in its important features, will be regarded as binding in all else?

column2: Is the free trade which the North sought in the formation of the Union, and for which the States generally agreed to give Congress the power to regulate commerce, to be trampled under foot by laws of obstruction, not giving to the citizens of the South that free transit across the territory of the Northern States which we might claim from any friendly state under Christendom; and is Congress to stand powerless by, on the doctrine of non-intervention?
column3: Is the free trade which the North sought in the formation of the Union, and for which the States generally agreed to give Congress the power to regulate commerce, to be trampled under foot by laws of obstruction, not giving to the citizens of the South that free transit across the territory of the Northern States which we might claim from any friendly state under Christendom; and is Congress to stand powerless by, on the doctrine of non intervention?

column2: We have a right to claim abstinence from interference with our rights from any Government on the earth.
column3: We have a right to claim abstinence from interference with our rights from any Government on the earth.

column2: Shall we claim no more from that which we have constituted for our own purposes, and which we support by draining our own means for its support?
column3: Shall we claim no more from that which we have constituted for our own purposes, and which we support by draining our own means for its support?

column2: We have had agitation, changing in its form, and gathering intensity, for the last forty years.
column3: We have had agitation, changing in its form, and gathering intensity, for the last forty years.

column2: It was first for political power, and directed against new States; now it has assumed a social form, is all-prevailing, and has reached the point of revolution and civil war.
column3: It was first for political power, and directed against new States; now it has assumed a social form, is all prevailing, and has reached the point of revolution and civil war.

column2: For it was only last fall that an overt act was committed by men who were sustained by arms and money, raised by extensive combination among the non-slaveholding States, to carry treasonable war against the State of Virginia, because now, as before the Revolution, and ever since, she held the African in bondage.
column3: For it was only last fall that an overt act was committed by men who were sustained by arms and money, raised by extensive combination among the non slaveholding States, to carry treasonable war against the State of Virginia, because now, as before the Revolution, and ever since, she held the African in bondage.

column2: This is part of the history and marks the necessity of the times.
column3: This is part of the history and marks the necessity of the times.

column2: It warns us to stop and reflect, to go back to the original standard, to measure our acts by the obligation of our fathers, by the pledges they made one to the other, to see whether we are conforming to our plighted faith, and to ask seriously, solemnly, looking each other inquiringly in the face, what we should do to save our country.
column3: It warns us to stop and reflect, to go back to the original standard, to measure our acts by the obligation of our fathers, by the pledges they made one to the other, to see whether we are conforming to our plighted faith, and to ask seriously, solemnly, looking each other inquiringly in the face, what we should do to save our country.

column2: This agitation being at first one of sectional pride for political power, has at last degenerated or grown up to (as you please) a trade. There are men who habitually set aside a portion of money which they are annually to apply to what are called "charitable purposes"--that is to say, so far as I understand it, to support some vagrant lecturer, whose purpose is agitation and mischief wherever he goes.
column3: This agitation being at first one of sectional pride for political power, has at last degenerated or grown up to (as you please) a trade. There are men who habitually set aside a portion of money which they are annually to apply to what are called "charitable purposes"--that is to say, so far as I understand it, to support some vagrant lecturer, whose purpose is agitation and mischief wherever he goes.

column2: This constitutes, therefore, a trade; a class of people are thus employed--employed for mischief, for incendiary purposes, perhaps not always understood by those who furnish the money; but such is the effect; such is the result of their action; and in this state of the case I call upon the Senate to affirm the great principles on which our institutions rest.
column3: This constitutes, therefore, a trade; a class of people are thus employed-employed for mischief, for incendiary purposes, perhaps not always understood by those who furnish the money; but such is the effect; such is the result of their action; and in this state of the case I call upon the Senate to affirm the great principles on which our institutions rest.

column2: In no spirit of crimination have I stated the reasons why I present it.
column3: In no spirit of crimination have I stated the reasons why I present it.

column2: For these reasons I call upon them now to restrain the growth of evil passion, and to bring back the public sense as far as in them lies, by earnest and united effort, if it may be, to crown our country with peace, and start it once more in its primal channel on a career of progressive prosperity and justice.
column3: For these reasons I call upon them now to restrain the growth of evil passion, and to bring back the public sense as far as in them lies, by earnest and united effort, if it may be, to crown our country with peace, and start it once more in its primal channel on a career of progressive prosperity and justice.

column2: The majority section can not be struggling for additional power in order to preserve their rights.
column3: The majority section can not be struggling for additional power in order to preserve their rights.

column2: If any of them ever believed in what is called Southern aggression, they know now they have the majority in the representative districts and in the electoral college.
column3: If any of them ever believed in what is called Southern aggression, they know now they have the majority in the representative districts and in the electoral college.

column2: They can not, therefore, fear an invasion of their rights.
column3: They can not, therefore, fear an invasion of their rights.

column2: They need no additional political power to protect them from that.
column3: They need no additional political power to protect them from that.

column2: The argument, then, or the reason on which this agitation commenced, has passed away; and yet we are asked, if a party hostile to our institutions shall gain possession of the Government, that we shall stand quietly by, and wait for an overt act.
column3: The argument, then, or the reason on which this agitation commenced, has passed away; and yet we are asked, if a party hostile to our institutions shall gain possession of the Government, that we shall stand quietly by, and wait for an overt act.

column2: Overt act!
column3: Overt act!

column2: Is not a declaration of war an overt act?
column3: Is not a declaration of war an overt act?

column2: What would be thought of a country that, after a declaration of war, and while the enemy's fleets were upon the sea, should wait until a city had been sacked before it would say that war existed, or resistance should be made?
column3: What would be thought of a country that, after a declaration of war, and while the enemy's fleets were upon the sea, should wait until a city had been sacked before it would say that war existed, or resistance should be made?

column2: The power of resistance consists, in no small degree, in meeting the evil at the outer gate.
column3: The power of resistance consists, in no small degree, in meeting the evil at the outer gate.

column2: I can speak for myself--and I have no right to speak for others--when I say, that, if I belonged to a party organized on the basis of making war on any section or interest in the United States, if I know myself, I would instantly quit it.
column3: I can speak for myself-and I have no right to speak for others-when I say, that, if I belonged to a party organized on the basis of making war on any section or interest in the United States, if I know myself, I would instantly quit it.

column2: We have made no war against you.
column3: We have made no war against you.

column2: We have asked no discrimination in our favor.
column3: We have asked no discrimination in our favor.

column2: We claim to have but the Constitution fairly and equally administered.
column3: We claim to have but the Constitution fairly and equally administered.

column2: To consent to less than this would be to sink in the scale of manhood; would be to make our posterity so degraded that they would curse this generation for robbing them of the rights their Revolutionary fathers bequeathed them....
column3: To consent to less than this would be to sink in the scale of manhood; would be to make our posterity so degraded that they would curse this generation for robbing them of the rights their Revolutionary fathers bequeathed them....

column2: Among the great purposes declared in the preamble of the Constitution is one to provide for the general welfare.
column3: Among the great purposes declared in the preamble of the Constitution is one to provide for the general welfare.

column2: Provision for the general welfare implies general fraternity.
column3: Provision for the general welfare implies general fraternity.

column2: This Union was not expected to be held together by coercion; the power of force as a means was denied. They sought, however, to bind it perpetually together with that which was stronger than triple bars of brass and steel--the ceaseless current of kind offices, renewing and renewed in an eternal flow, and gathering volume and velocity as it rolled.
column3: This Union was not expected to be held together by coercion; the power of force as a means was denied. They sought, however, to bind it perpetually together with that which was stronger than triple bars of brass and steel-the ceaseless current of kind offices, renewing and renewed in an eternal flow, and gathering volume and velocity as it rolled.

column2: It was a function intended not for the injury of any.
column3: It was a function intended not for the injury of any.

column2: It declared its purpose to be the benefit of all. Concessions which were made between the different States in the Convention prove the motive.
column3: It declared its purpose to be the benefit of all. Concessions which were made between the different States in the Convention prove the motive.

column2: Each gave to the other what was necessary to it; what each could afford to spare.
column3: Each gave to the other what was necessary to it; what each could afford to spare.

column2: Young as a nation, our triumphs under this system have had no parallel in human history.
column3: Young as a nation, our triumphs under this system have had no parallel in human history.

column2: We have tamed a wilderness; we have spanned a continent.
column3: We have tamed a wilderness; we have spanned a continent.

column2: We have built up a granary that secures the commercial world against the fear of famine.
column3: We have built up a granary that secures the commercial world against the fear of famine.

column2: Higher than all this, we have achieved a moral triumph.
column3: Higher than all this, we have achieved a moral triumph.

column2: We have received, by hundreds of thousands, a constant tide of immigrants--energetic, if not well educated, fleeing, some from want, some from oppression, some from the penalties of violated law--received them into our society; and by the gentle suasion of a Government which exhibits no force, by removing want and giving employment, they have subsided into peaceful citizens, and have increased the wealth and power of our country.
column3: We have received, by hundreds of thousands, a constant tide of immigrants-energetic, if not well educated, fleeing, some from want, some from oppression, some from the penalties of violated law-received them into our society; and by the gentle suasion of a Government which exhibits no force, by removing want and giving employment, they have subsided into peaceful citizens, and have increased the wealth and power of our country.

column2: If, then, this temple so blessed, and to the roof of which we were about to look to see it extended over the continent, giving a protecting arm to infant republics that need it--if this temple is tottering on its pillars, what, I ask, can be a higher or nobler duty for the Senate to perform than to rush to its pillars and uphold them, or be crushed in the attempt?
column3: If, then, this temple so blessed, and to the roof of which we were about to look to see it extended over the continent, giving a protecting arm to infant republics that need it-if this temple is tottering on its pillars, what, I ask, can be a higher or nobler duty for the Senate to perform than to rush to its pillars and uphold them, or be crushed in the attempt?

column2: We have tampered with a question which has grown in magnitude by each year's delay.
column3: We have tampered with a question which has grown in magnitude by each year's delay.

column2: It requires to be plainly met--the truth to be told.
column3: It requires to be plainly met-the truth to be told.

column2: The patriotism and the sound sense of the people, whenever the Federal Government from its high places of authority shall proclaim the truth in unequivocal language, will, in my firm belief, receive and approve it.
column3: The patriotism and the sound sense of the people, whenever the Federal Government from its high places of authority shall proclaim the truth in unequivocal language, will, in my firm belief, receive and approve it.

column2: But so long as we deal, like the Delphic oracle, in words of double meaning, so long as we attempt to escape from responsibility, and exhibit our fear to declare the truth by the fact that we do not act upon it, we must expect speculative theory to occupy the mind of the public, and error to increase as time rolls on.
column3: But so long as we deal, like the Delphic oracle, in words of double meaning, so long as we attempt to escape from responsibility, and exhibit our fear to declare the truth by the fact that we do not act upon it, we must expect speculative theory to occupy the mind of the public, and error to increase as time rolls on.

column2: But, if the sad fate should be ours, for this most minute cause, to destroy our Government, the historian who shall attempt philosophically to examine the question will, after he has put on his microscopic glasses and discovered it, be compelled to cry out, "Veritably so the unseen insect in the course of time destroys the mighty oak!" Now, I believe--may I not say I believe? if not, then I hope--there is yet time, by the full, explicit declaration of the truth, to disabuse the popular mind, to arouse the popular heart, to expose the danger from lurking treason and ill-concealed hostility; to rally a virtuous people to their country's rescue, who, circling closer and deeper as the storm gathers fury, around the ark of their fathers' covenant, will place it in security, there happily to remain a sign of fraternity, justice, and equality, to our remotest posterity.
column3: But, if the sad fate should be ours, for this most minute cause, to destroy our Government, the historian who shall attempt philosophically to examine the question will, after he has put on his microscopic glasses and discovered it, be compelled to cry out, "Veritably so the unseen insect in the course of time destroys the mighty oak!" Now, I believe-may I not say I believe? if not, then I hope-there is yet time, by the full, explicit declaration of the truth, to disabuse the popular mind, to arouse the popular heart, to expose the danger from lurking treason and ill concealed hostility; to rally a virtuous people to their country's rescue, who, circling closer and deeper as the storm gathers fury, around the ark of their fathers' covenant, will place it in security, there happily to remain a sign of fraternity, justice, and equality, to our remotest posterity.
